thread.title: Eclectic range caters to Mackay film lovers
thread.title_full: Eclectic range caters to Mackay film lovers

title: Eclectic range caters to Mackay film lovers
text:
Eclectic range caters to Mackay film lovers Lucy Smith | 8th Oct 2015 10:48 AM Lucy Smith The Crow's Egg is a funny, charming South Indian tale of two mischievous and resourceful brothers from a Chennai slum who become determined to taste pizza for the very first time. Contributed Contributed Local Real Estate Cars For Sale 
AS MANAGER of the Travelling Film Festival, Alicia Emery had the enviable task of compiling a program of films especially for Mackay. 
During the past year she's viewed about 100 films, searching the world for the best films. 
Organised by the Sydney Film Festival, the event is Australia's longest running travelling film festival, and will visit 19 locations in Queensland, New South Wales and the Northern Territory. 
"We try to have a different program for every single location," Ms Emery said. 
"None of them are identical, and that's because the audiences are different across each location." 
Ms Emery said the fact Mackay already had an established Film and Arts group influenced her film choices. 
"For Mackay audiences, there's a group there that is very interested in film, our audiences there have quite a good knowledge of film and want to see more challenging films," she said. 
"It's also about presenting some light films, because no one wants a program full of depressing or dark films." 
The festival will open next Friday at 7pm with film, The Crow's Egg, that has been dubbed a new Slumdog Millionaire. 
"It's really delightful, it's an Indian tale and it's a real crowd pleaser," Ms Emery said. 
The Crow's Egg tells the story of two mischievous and resourceful brothers from a Chennai slum who become determined to taste pizza for the very first time. 
Ms Emery said the Travelling Film Festival program featured a range of genres and nationalities, including films from India, US, Australia, Germany, Ireland and Denmark. 
"We want a diverse program, we want something that will appeal to all kinds of ages and interests," she said. 
The Travelling Film Festival will open at the Mackay City Cinemas on Friday, October 16 with a screening of The Crow's Egg and finish on Sunday, October 19. 
Single tickets are $14 for an adult, or a five-film pass can be purchased for $53, or a nine-film pass for $75. 
Concession prices are also available, book at ww.sff.org.au/Mackay. entertainment
